Rate of perceived exhaustion (RPE) Rate of Perceived Exhaustion (RPE) is a scale of 1 to 10 which determines how hard a set felt.\n\n10: Maximal, no reps left in the tank\n9: One rep left in the tank\n8: Two reps left in the tank\n7: Weight moves quickly with maximal force\n6: Weight moves quickly with moderate force\n5: Most warm-up weights\n4: Recovery; usually twenty plus rep sets\nAn RPE below four isn’t important.
Warmup During warm up gradually increase the weight starting from an empty bar to the first working set. Increase/decrease 5% of total weight to go to the next/previous RPE.\n\ne.g.: 10 reps x 10 kg @ RPE 6. To go to RPE 7 increase weight to 10.5kg
Exercises Before performing any exercise, please look up the correct form or ask a member of staff to give you some advice.\n\nIf you can not perform an exercise due to an injury or lack of equipment please substitute it with a similar one
Intensity As a beginner you want to create a solid foundation by prioritising movement patterns instead of using high loads.
